commentBody: Easy, fun, loved it!

Never played the game.  Still have no idea why there are 1's and 2's in the black squares.  (Maybe it's in the column; I haven't looked yet.) 

Solved with little difficulty anyway (apparently 25% faster than my Thursday average), but the theme didn't do anything to help the solve.

Found it interesting that two different computer games with the rebus word at the beginning exist and are in the puzzle.  My experience with video games ends with Pac-Man, circa 1980.

Maybe gamers like Andrzej may get a kick from this theme.  To me, it was just there.

Nice gimmick, but it was poorly executed.

The fill and the clueing were fine, but nothing special.

This was too easy for a Thursday.

With some refining and better editing, this could have been much better. Very disappointing.

3/10.
Loved this puzzle. Fun to find the mines after a long time!
Had a blast!!  Favorite puzzle this year.
Had a great time! Well done.
AWESOME PUZZLE!

Loved this -- and once I figured out the theme (which was when I hit 62A, "why does MINESWEEPER not fit? Oh, duh") it did help me figure out the puzzle faster. 4D having four letters confused me initially ("ad hocs" seemed awkward) until I got a (MINE) in there.

There could even have been an unchecked, unclued middle square ... *evil grin*
Loved this!! I loved minesweeper back in the day so I found this a lot of fun. The numbers definitely helped my solve. My favorite for the year also. Not too much US centric cluing for this Aussie.

Rebus light. Very light.

It may be a  [Classic computer game...], but I'd never heard of it. Of course that didn't slow my solve. 

The numbers would have helped if I had needed help finding the rebuses. Did anyone know what they meant -- before reading the column -- *and* use them to find the rebuses?

A rebus puzzle can't get much easier than this, can it?

I smiled when I figured out the rebus and that the puzzle was a riff on MINESWEEPER.  When i was working, MINESWEEPER was on the computer and I played many a game when I had downtime, or when I was on particularly boring conference calls. In this puzzle, spotting the rebus speeded the solve and success was MINEALLMINE.  

I liked the clue for ABACUS.

I was DETER[1]D to beat my average, and I did. BOOM!

Not the hardest Thursday puzzle, but clever and fun.

such an interesting concept and perfectly executed
one of my all-time favorite solves
was a big fan of minesweeper back in the day, started my fandom of logic games
LinkedIn Queens is quickly becoming one of my favorites to play currently
This is the best puzzle of the year. The competition is over. Take a bow, Aidan.
I'm always curious how constructors pitch fun grids like this to the editors in their cover letters. Thanks for the walk back to memory lane.

Is nostalgia the lowest form of happiness? Today’s minesweeper will be a generational divide for certain.  Those of us who played it for hours, and those who did not. 

Very clever.  Go feel some grass before the frosts begin.

Love minesweeper. Very addictive game. Figured out the rebus pretty quickly. Did not think this was easy otherwise. Never seen Ad Ho(mine)n before this nor Aegean Airlines. However. Clyde of Bonnie and Clyde, Iago (nice classic bad guys) just fell into place for me, and as a SCUBA diver who has dive the Great Barrier Reef, The Great Astrolabe reef, California, and Blue Hole, Self was automatic as well. Bling to anyone who can tell us where the Astrolabe reef is without looking it up. ;)

I really liked the puzzle, but one clue that I just didn't get was the Spanish greeting. I mean, I figured it out that they wanted alo, but I'm only familiar with hola. Not even ola, which I think is Italian.
I thoroughly enjoyed revisiting this BLAST from the past. So much so, I just downloaded Minesweeper. Great puzzle!
KALE?
Oh, that was SO much fun!
I appreciate the craft of the puzzle, and some might say it's their favorite. But, it wasn't mine.
Wooooowwwwwww, was this a great puzzle 💣💣💣

never saw the game.  never played it.  likely never will.  tipped off by his eminence, solved the puzzle with no inkling of the theme.  then wikipediaed minesweeper to learn about a thing i never knew and thought:  cool game.  and then i thought:  very cool puzzle.  especially retroactively sussing out its use of 1s and 2s.  and then i thought:  this is why the times crosswords are so cool.

I spent many absorbed hours playing MineSweeper, and I just loved this puzzle.  To me, and with my life experiences, this is a classic puzzle, one for the ages.

However, not having seen MineSweep, I would think this would crank up the difficulty several levels.

I don't think I've ever had a puzzle that fit me more perfectly.

If you're old enough to remember, Minesweeper was part of Windows 3.0 through Vista. If you have the patience for it, it's a fun little logic game. I don't. So, I occasionally set the board to it's largest dimensions and fewest mines. Instant winner! Arrgh!
Oh, I really enjoyed this puzzle!  Kudos to the author, and thanks for the trip down memory lane.

Once of my fastest Thursdays, despite having no idea what the numbers were for until I read the column. Didn't need them because the squares with MINEs were obvious to me. 

TIL that PUPU platters are associated with American Chinese cuisine. I've only had them in Hawaii, but a lot of Hawaiian cuisine  comes from Asia, so it makes sense. Also? I've frequently wondered why PUPU is not allowed in the Spelling Bee, and TIL that it's actually two words. Not that that's a requirement to be banned from the Bee. There are still plenty of other perfectly common (in my experience) single food words that are not accepted. Argh.
Had heard of the game, but never played. Really enjoyed MINE ALL MINE, Bwahaha.
Great crossword, but an extremely easy Minesweeper board! I was a little disappointed that it didn’t accept asterisks for the mines.

I knew why the numbers were there.  I actually played a game of mine sweeper in the last two weeks…and the quickly deleted it…sometimes old games seem like a good idea and then you play a round or two and remember why you stopped playing.

It took me multiple laps thru the board to figure out that I didn’t have preeminently in 17 across and that I needed to find another word.
I played A LOT of the game, and I’m really bummed I lost this one. Flags would have been nicer.

Surprised how many people never heard of it. I guess I'm in that gap generation who grew up before high speed internet but with a computer in every room. And games in those computers. I understood the theme the second I saw the grid

I never got the opportunity to play this game, but I had definitely heard of MINE SWEEPER. What impressed me most was that a current college student was not only aware of the game but actually created a grid around it 🤯  I caught on to the rebus with PRO(MINE)NTLY. I originally thought the theme might solve to MINE CRAFT  until I saw that was the answer to 24D 😆 

Mad props to you, Aidan. I’m saving your email address!!
On my iPad, the numbers didn’t appear until I’d solved the puzzle. Anyone else have the same experience? But I’ve never played the game, so they wouldn’t have helped.
I enjoyed the puzzle! I'm 47 and played SOOOOOO many games of minesweeper! I loved the game.
As soon as I figured out the trick, I placed mines around the puzzle. I absolutely adored this!
I absolutely loved this!

Ah. Minesweeper. Often a diversion from work one should have been doing on the computer. 

I didn't immediately recognize the purpose of the numbers (perhaps because there were so few of them) but when looking at MINESWEEPER in proximity to UNDERMINE/DETERMINE, the light bulb finally turned on, and my appreciation for the puzzle increased many fold.

A very clever and enjoyable puzzle.

Twenty-two minutes of treacherous waters, but the MINEs blew up after I was safely done.  I don't know whether to be pleased or chagrined that I never got the reason for the numbers, but I'll take the win anyway.

I thoroughly enjoyed this. It’s been a long time since I thought about or played MINESWEEPER but it brings back fond memories. I can see why if you don’t know the game it becomes a straightforward rebus puzzle and less interesting, although I thought it was fairly hard until I got to the revealer, and then I did use the numbers to place the mines. It was well executed with a lot of thoughtful, informative, and fun clues and not a lot of glue—I’m a big fan of POIROT and I thought the clue for UPDATE was inspired. Finally I really want to know what’s going on at Harvey Mudd college with all these constructors there? Maybe the admissions committee loves crosswords  and gives extra points for students who show interest? Are they teaching a crossword course? I don’t know but there’s a lot of them and they have been terrific!
I loved this! A wonderful nostalgia puzzle.
Minesweeper: a blast from the past.

This puzzle made me unexpectedly emotional. My dear mother, may she rest in peace, loved playing games—especially Minesweeper on her old Mac desktop and the New York Times crossword. Seeing them joined together in today’s theme brought back so many memories of her. It was a bittersweet reminder of her joy in these little daily challenges, ones we often solved. Thank you for creating something that touched me so personally and let me feel close to her again, even if only for a moment.

I always print out the puzzle. Today, my puzzle had no numbers in any of the black squares! Fortunately, I didn't need them. In fact, trying to figure out why there were numbers would only have slowed me down. I should add that although I've certainly heard of Minesweeper, I have never played it.  That certainly didn't hold me back from solving this very enjoyable puzzle.

I was addicted to Minesweeper as a teenager (as my PB of 59 seconds on the expert level attests), and this wonderful puzzle (which took a bit longer) brought back a lot of great memories. Thanks, Aidan!
Mine-d blown!
Brilliant! One of my favorite Thursday puzzles yet!
Phenomenal blend of cluing and theme, total delight.
Minesweeper! Loved the game, love this puzzle! And the cross of HIS EMINENCE and Mine ALL MINE could be a minefield.

As far as I can tell I've finished the puzzle. Are you suppossed to enter (rebus) the word "mine" where a mine would appear to complete the word? I never played Minesweeper but I never thought it might be in anyway important to doing a crossword puzzle.

That was really enjoyable.
If anyone wants to try Minesweeper, and you have Netflix and a tablet, they have a nice version.

Woo-wee!
What a fun puzzle!

As soon as I opened the puzzle and saw the numbers, I knew I was gonna be in for a good time. Math? Magic squares? Who knows,but let's find out.

I immediately got the revealer of MINE SWEEPER (which brings back memories), but wait! It doesn't fit! Let's come back to it. Off to the down entries, and low and behold, the answer had to be MINECRAFT. Aha! A rebus!

And then everything fell into place. I was totally on the same wavelength as the constructor, getting ABACUS, WATCH and ET AL on the first pass, and finishing in half my Thursday average. But every one of those minutes was a joy.

Thank you.

Reasonable puzzle, light for a Thursday as others have indicated.  I appreciate that the rebuses worked both ways, but I don't really enjoy it when it's the same word every time.  Makes a lot of sense for this theme though.  There were a few times I tried Minesweeper when I'd glazed over on Solitaire, but I just never liked it at all.  It seems many others here did.

I had "age" instead of "ago" for a long time until I reasoned out how ago could fit the clue.  I thought "regale" seemed wrong - I always took it to mean talked to, not general entertaining - but the online dictionaries seem split on the matter, with MW favoring the interpretation here.

Pin number was an excellent clue.

Dang that was a good puzzle!!! I got to brush off my old minesweeper skills. I once had to delete minesweeper off my PC because I was spending hours every day avoiding my college class work. Now I avoid my work work and my life’s work doing NYT crosswords.
Brilliant. Put the boom back in this Boomer.
Christina Iverson's Mini was Absolutely Fabulous today... Masterclass Wordplay

I found this the perfect Thursday puzzle. I solved it exactly in my average time for this day in the week, and I thought the trick was neat, if perhaps slightly too easy to understand, but only if you ever played MINESWEEPER. If you have not... Ouch!

I got my first Windows PC in 1993. My relationship with the game MIJESWEEPER was... Complicated. Impatience and limited intelligence were to blame: I never waited long enough to get the data to extrapolate the positions of the mines from, and I also didn't bother to take into account the data I already had. Thus, I clicked on mines way too often for the game to be fun, so I never played it much. I preferred Solitaire 🤣.

I had to wrestle with the fill in places. I didn't need lookups in the end but I still don't understand some stuff. What is a DANISH and a BEAR CLAW? I only know the literal meanings of both words, and I think danish may be used to describe some dairy spread?

I'm about to walk to take Lucyfer the puppy to the groomer for our 8 AM (CET) appointment. Expect an update with some probably quite cute photos later today 😃

This brought back memories from several decades ago.   I had forgotten that back then I had played a game called Mine Sweeper.  I was able to 'deduce' that the word MINE would be an everywhere rebus when I 'determine'd that 'deduce' wouldn't work for last four acrosses of 48D.   So MINEsweeper reveal came to me naturally in 62A .... But it wasn't until I finished the puzzle and the graphics popped up that I recalled that I used to play this game addictively back in the Windows 95 era.     My one trip up that almost stopped me from getting a clean shove was that I put AGE as the answer to 3D.... Took me a while to find mistake and realize that AGO would give me prOminently for the across.    Was a happy solve when I found that.
When I filled in my first rebus square, it blew me away.

Thanks for this! I loved it,a pretty flawless Puzzle and first rate theme. It was fun slowly remembering details of the game as I solved the puzzle. I, too, happily wasted many hours in the 1990s playing minesweeper and solitaire on early Windows computers!
Really really enjoyed this one! Had trouble with the West but I'm going to be smiling all day.
This whole thing was on my WAVElength.

I would like to remind everyone that Aidan is 19, and also that he has a terrific sense of humor – you will agree with me if you look at his picture on XwordInfo, and it’s well worth a look. ( https://www.xwordinfo.com/Author/Aidan_Deshong ). My biggest TIL today? The game Minesweeper! Somehow, I missed that phenomenon, and I’m sorry I did after reading the comments from the grateful and nostalgic commenters today. Despite that, there was still, for me, a huge heap of puzzlejoy. I loved those numbers in the grid. Before filling in the first letter, they hooked me, and I couldn’t wait to see why they were there. Then, after filling in the last letter, still, what a riddle to crack for Minesweeper-ignorant me! I kept trying to figure out their significance, and let me tell you, that kind of riddle-attacking work is what my brain lives for. Oh, it never did figure it out, but man, the trying was divine. Two more things – Standing O for the clue [Pin number?], elegant and saturated with wordplay. Plus, what a superbly built grid! More, Aiden, more please! This was a jewel, and thank you!

Oooh! One of the most unusual puzzle finds I've ever encountered. Two puzzles actually. One - a Monday from February 24, 1986 by Virginia L. Yates. The other one a Monday from July 29, 1991 - also by Virginia L. Yates. And.. those two puzzles had exactly the same theme answers in exactly the same locations. Those were: MYLUCKYSTAR LUCKYINLOVE LUCKYTOBEME LUCKBEALADY But the other answers in those puzzles were different. Both edited by Eugene T. Maleska so he had to know. I might over time do some more searches to see if that ever happened before (or later). Just seems very odd. Oh.. and here are the links to those two puzzles: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=2/24/1986&g=28&d=A https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=7/29/1991&g=59&d=A .....

Quick observation about E-SCOOTERS, other than they're an annoyance in a crowded tourist city; I remember when the RAZR first hit the market. A year or so later, it contained a seat. Not long afterwards, it contained a gasoline motor. The young pre-teens went from pumping with their foot, to seated pumping, to seated with a gas can strapped to the running board. I'll spare the “back in my day” part.

Speaking of mines, I found myself right up against one last night.

True story.  It was dark, I had a flashlight, and I was returning from taking out the garbage, when from behind a large bush a huge bear appeared. We were suddenly face-to-face, two feet apart, both totally surprised.  (Bears and humans co-exist in our neighborhood; we usually keep our distance from each other.)

I’m still laughing over how I reacted – and it was pure reaction; I had no time to think – I stood tall, arms raised overhead, and I kept repeating frantically and earnestly to the bear, “I’m sorry!  I’m sorry!  I’m sorry!”

Then it aped me!  It stood tall and raised its arms overhead as well.  After a moment, the air suddenly felt safe, and we each went our own way.  Thank heavens this mine didn't explode.

And out of such moments a life is made.

Danish, bear claws, croissants, etc. are examples of what chefs call "laminate doughs"--flour, water, and fat (usually butter) are combined and kneaded, by repetitive folding, to create a dough that consists of innumerable, thin, alternating layers of flour and fat. Just those two, and you have puff pastry ("pâte feuilletée"); add yeast, and you have croissant dough; add eggs to that, and you have danish dough.

Despite the name, they are Austrian(-ish) in origin: the French term for them, collectively, is "viennoiserie."

My mom, who was born and grew up in China between the two world wars, brought her abacus with her when she came to the US in the late 1940's. I have childhood memories of how fast her fingers and the beads moved, and the clacking sounds that were an accompaniment.

PUTTINONTHERITZ and BLOWININTHEWIND Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=7/30/1996&g=37&d=A And then... a Saturday from March 21, 2015 by Frederick J. Healy. A rare puzzle with three grid spanning across triple stacks - each synchronously placed top, middle and bottom. Those stacks: JUMPINJACKFLASH AHOOSIERHOLIDAY NOCAUSEFORALARM ORANGEPOPSICLE TURNEDTHETABLES ATTENTIONPLEASE ONEAFTERANOTHER GETSTOFIRSTBASE ISTHISSEATTAKEN Can't even imagine what it must have taken to work all of that out. @Steve L the 1s and 2s in the game Minesweeper indicate how many mines touch that square. Including corners. Properly applied to this puzzle it also tells the solver where the rebus squares might be. @Jamie
If you are, like me, of that age where you played Minesweeper incessantly at one point in life but haven't thought about it for at least 15 years, this puzzle was incredible.  When I first saw the board with the 1's and 2's listed, I didn't make the connection to Minesweeper, but once I did and understood I had to enter MINE in the right places, all these memories that I didn't really know that I had of late nights playing this game came rushing into my head.

The closest comparison I've had to a similar sensation came from a production of Thornton Wilder's play Our Town in a small theater, directed by the great David Cromer.  At one point, one of the characters asks to go back to her childhood, and she gets transported back to the kitchen of her childhood home, where her mother is frying bacon.  In this production, the actress playing her mother is frying actual bacon, and you hear the grease spitting and you can smell the aroma of bacon cooking as it fills up the room.  As an adult, I never cook slabs of bacon, but my mom did for weekend breakfasts when I was little, and the smell and sound of bacon cooking opened up an association and a memory that I didn't know I had.

So, for me, this is the puzzle of the year.  Especially because Aidan is a college student, who presumably isn't of that age where Minesweeper has a hazy nostalgia.  Aidan, I can't wait to see what you come up with next.

1, means that black square is touching one MINE (bomb).

@Keith in the game Minesweeper, the numbers in the squares indicate how many mines are adjacent to them. In this way you can figure out, by process of elimination, which squares are safe to click. Usually somewhere along the way, though, you end up with a 50/50 shot.

@D

I have tremendous respect for others’ differing opinions as I hope my posts demonstrate, including yours. If I am inclined to defend constructors it’s because—I want to support them to continue to give me hours of enjoyment, when I personally feel they have; sometimes people don’t understand the technical restrictions facing them; I want to promote types of puzzles I enjoy so they continue to be created; and I’m a human being who doesn’t like to see people’s feelings hurt so try to prop them up when I can. I have no issue with reasoned criticism, or even unreasoned when it is directed to, as Barry said, “the product”. Although I will say it mystifies me when people say “I hated this puzzle” with no further comment. What’s the point? I don’t know whether editors take the time to read this, but I know constructors do, and if I saw comments directed to certain clues or types of construction that are frequently criticized I wouldn’t hesitate to try to avoid them. I know as a constructor I am much more sensitive to Naticks now because of these comments and I avoid OCTOPI within an inch of my life.
